docs.lead_paragraph: A recent study in India suggests that breast-feeding alone may not provide enough sustenance to babies in the developing nations when their mothers are severely malnourished. The report adds fuel to a debate about a decade-old campaign by the World Health Organization and other United Nations agencies that advocate an exclusive reliance on breast milk for the first six months of life.

headline.main: Researchers Raise Fresh Issues in Breast-Feeding Debate

docs.abstract: Recent study in India suggests breast-feeding alone may not provide enough sustenance to babies in developing nations when their mothers are severely malnourished; adds fuel to debate about decade-old drive by World Health Organization and other United Nations agencies that advocate exclusive reliance on breast milk for first six months of life; study concludes babies as young as 2 or 3 months should get supplementary liquids or soft foods when mother is malnourished; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A recent study in India suggests that breast-feeding alone may not provide enough sustenance to babies in the developing nations when their mothers are severely malnourished.    The report adds fuel to a debate about a decade-old campaign by the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, more Americans have been heading to the weight room. A recent survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that one in five people lifts weights regularly. The Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association reports an 89 percent increase in the number of people lifting free weights and a 50 percent increase in those using weight machines from 1987 to 1999.

headline.main: Evaluating Pains and Gains Of Weight Lifting Regimen

docs.abstract: University of Arkansas study finds that rise in weight training has led to sharp increase in related injuries; experts, noting rate of injuries has outpaced increases in participation among certain groups, suspect many people may not be lifting correctly or may be risking overload injuries by trying to do too much in short amount of time; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Over the last decade, more Americans have been heading to the weight room.    A recent survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates that one in five people lifts weights regularly. The Sporting Goods Manufacturers Association...

docs.lead_paragraph: Citing ''rare but serious risks'' from Lotronex, a drug prescribed for women with irritable bowel syndrome, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered that a warning pamphlet be attached to each bottle of pills to alert consumers to early signs of dangerous side effects. The order on Thursday, the first time that such a pamphlet has been required for any drug, came about because serious side effects have been reported in 15 patients since Lotronex was approved in February. It is used to treat women with chronic diarrhea resulting from the bowel syndrome.

headline.main: Side Effects Of a Drug Spur Alert To Users

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration orders that warning pamphlets be attached to bottles of Lotronex, drug prescribed to treat chronic diarrhea in women with irritable bowel syndrome, to alert consumers to early signs of rare but serious side effects, including severe constipation and ischemic colitis; says benefits of drug outweigh risks; Public Citizen's Health Research Group director, Sidney M Wolfe, says drug should be taken off market because syndrome is not life-threatening, while side effects could be (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: John McCain's unfortunate return bout with melanoma should serve as a wake-up call for the millions of Americans -- especially young Americans -- who still worship the sun, skimp on sunscreen and bare their skin to UV radiation to just within the limits of decency. It should also remind everyone of the importance of self-vigilance. Since no one knows your skin and its many markings better than you, you have primary responsibility for checking often for any changes that could herald skin cancer.

headline.main: Yet Another Reminder: Forget the Suntan

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on preventing and detecting melanoma, serious form of skin cancer; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dick Richards of Anderson, Calif., goes for his physical every year, and his doctor jots down his height and weight. The doctor does not react to the fact that each year Mr. Richards is shorter. Maybe he never looks back over Mr. Richards' file to compare, or if he does notice the change, he does not think twice about it.

headline.main: The 'Women's Disease' That Also Strikes Men

docs.abstract: Strong link between osteoporosis and women causes many doctors to overlook disease in men, who account for only 20 percent of 10 million Americans with osteoporosis or low bone mass; lack of awareness among doctors and men has led to delays in diagnosis and treatment; disease manifests itself later in life in men than women, with fractures starting to increase around age 60 in women and between 65 and 70 in men; doctors treat men with therapies that have proven effective in women, but not yet in men; table of secondary causes of disease in men; photos (M)
